text: good morning and welcome again to Black
Hat Europe and to our mainstage program
This is a new addition to Black Hat this
year So we are very excited to kick it
off here today It this is uh this is
part of our expanded content program in
all of the Black Hat events around the
world Uh all aimed at providing you with
more content more actionable insights
and of course more opportunities to
connect with your peers in the global
cyber security community Our goal for
this program for the black hat mainstage
is to hear from some of the thought
leaders from within the cyber security
industry So CEOs entrepreneurs heads of
strategy and really to ask them uh that
to provide their perspectives on
important topics trends and and
developments
Danny Jenkins is one of those thought
leaders and is joining us today to
address the important topic of supply
chain security something we've been
hearing a lot about in the news since
the uh now infamous Solar Winds attack
back in
2020 Danny is a leading cyber security
expert with over two decades of
experience building and securing large
corporate networks In 2017 he co-founded
zero trust endpoint security company
Threat Locker and he's made it his
mission to educate industry
professionals about the latest cyber
security
threats Please join me in welcoming to
the Black Hat main stage Danny Jenkins
co-founder and CEO of Threat Locker
Good afternoon everybody So let's talk a
little bit about supply chains and what
the risks what the real risks are and
what the perceived risks are of supply
chain Now first of all what do we do now
to protect oursel from the supply chain
most companies larger companies will go
through some kind of assessment when
they onboard a product So they'll ask
questions like is it in the cloud what
data is it storing what
um sorry is in the cloud what data is it
storing is it payment credit card data
is it patient information is it medical
information is it confidential they'll
go things like "Let's assess the risks."
So they'll look at a SIG questionnaire
maybe a SOCK 2 report an ISO report
something like that to see is the
company we're doing business with a
secure company And then from that
they'll either decide this software is
worth accepting the risk And I say
accepting because there's always a risk
when you onboard a vendor Is it not
worth accepting so or we were going to
reject the vendor and not on board them
or we going to transfer the risk to
something like insurance And that's
really our three
options Now the big one that comes up
quite often is what is more secure the
cloud or on prem and I'm quite often
confronted with someone saying "No we
can't do cloud for security reasons."
And I want to talk about that a little
bit because it's not necessarily as true
as people think So if we think about the
cloud the first thing we have to think
about is the cloud The service is now
hosted on the internet And the problem
is when we host something on the
internet is we're sharing the internet
with the whole world We're sharing it
with Russia or North Korea We're sharing
it with China We're sharing it with
Russia And most terrifying of all we're
sharing it with
Liverpool Now with that in mind we think
okay I'm going to publish a service I'm
going to buy a service whether it's a
CRM whether it's a healthcare service
and I'm going to have it in the cloud
And that's a potential risk cuz somebody
could access that from outside But then
start looking at things like maybe
Exchange So if you said "I don't want to
do Office 365 I want to use Exchange on
prem I'm more secure." But let's think
about this When you have an Exchange on
prem server you're probably opening that
port 443 to the internet so your users
can access it from their phones And if
you're not opening it through 443 you're
requiring a VPN connection which adds
its own set of problems and security
weaknesses And if we think back to 2022
there was an a series of Exchange
vulnerabilities that allowed attackers
to gain access to your Exchange server
And essentially the way it worked is
they would point at your exchange server
and through a vulnerability they would
exploit the IIS and they would change
your offline address book URL which
seems pretty insignificant in
insignificant Now when a user tries to
connect to the exchange server to
download their URL so we saw this in a
number of cases in the in the wild What
it would do is it wouldn't download the
malicious payload to their computer
which is what I thought it would have
done when I read the vulnerability it
actually download the malicious payload
to the server and at this point it's
dormant on the
server and when an admin logged into the
server it put it in the startup folder
so when a domain admin logged in it
would run that script that malicious
payload and it could potentially do
anything it wanted in one of the cases
we saw it was actually a customer who
came into us and said hey you guys
stopped a major breach on our system and
I said what happened and they said you
stopped a batch file from running Now
when he said that I genuinely thought it
was a false positive I was like "Are you
sure that a batch file on your server is
a major exploit?" So he showed me the
batch file and we actually took it and
put it into our lab And we followed the
same exploit that happened And when the
batch file ran what it did is it reached
out to the internet and downloaded a
PowerShell file which then reached out
to the internet again and downloaded
another PowerShell file because
apparently hackers like to go through
lots of steps This one was B 64 encoded
for no reason other than to make it more
difficult for AVs to read it which then
downloaded reached out to the internet
downloaded an executable and created a
group policy to push out ransomware to
the entire
organization Now this comes back to is
the cloud more secure or is onrem more
secure sec secure because in this case
even if the same vulnerability existed
in the cloud which it didn't but let's
assume it did because it's the same
software the damage to the customer
would be that my exchange data was
exposed my email data which is pretty
big damage but that's a lot less than
someone actually got onto my entire
active directory pushed out a group
policy to me my entire organization to
deploy ransomware which then uploaded
all of our files to the internet and
encrypted all of our files So it's not
as simple as is cloud more secure or
less secure because quite often when
you're thinking about the cloud you're
actually taking a risk out of your
organization and just exposing that by
itself So if the data isn't that
important it's almost always more secure
to put it in the
cloud What about servers that don't have
open ports because in that case I said
well we had an open port someone
connected to 443 What about a program
that I ran inside my organization versus
outside so say maybe a system monitoring
tool if I had it in the cloud someone
could log into that tool They can make
changes maybe an RMM IT management tool
Whereas if it's inside my organization
it has no open ports Nobody can do that
But we saw in 2019 2020 that wasn't the
case Solar Winds Orion threat actors
nation state sponsored threat actors
gained access to Solar Wind source code
to their git essentially They then did a
test code injection in October 2019
realized that it wasn't detected and
implemented the Sunbursts code in
February
2020 This was then packaged by Solar
Winds and pushed out to all of their
clients as an update
This didn't require any open ports in
the environment It essentially allowed
any attacker or in this case nation
states backd dooror into the
business So when we think about this we
have to acknowledge that there are risks
both ways and just because something is
on prem it doesn't mean it's more secure
The other thing we need to consider is
it's all about the endpoint anyway
because it doesn't matter whether you
use the cloud or whether you use onrem
All of your data has to be accessible in
an unencrypted and readable format from
the endpoint Now does that mean
endpoints aren't encrypted no they are
encrypted But humans can't read
encrypted data We can have encryption in
transit We can have encryption in rest
But at the end of the day if I want to
open a word document or a financial file
it has to be readable in unencrypted
data So when we think about where are
the biggest risks we have to think about
the endpoint And going back to 2019
there was a vulnerability in Internet
Explorer that allowed any website you
visited to run any PowerShell command it
wanted to on your computer without any
interaction from the user Now I know if
you were using Internet Explorer in 2019
you probably deserve
that Zoom in 2020 however was very very
popular and it had a similar
vulnerability where you could launch
PowerShell directly from Zoom and then
we saw Felina in 2022 This one scares me
a lot because I know as a security
professional that if I get a Word
document I can open that Word document
and it's relatively safe and I can click
through the 15 warnings Microsoft gives
me but as long as I don't click enable
macros and I'm safe Now users don't know
that but I know that Now the Felina
vulnerability was slightly different
because every morning when I wake up I
read all of the I read the news and see
what big vulnerabilities are out there
and there's loads of them every single
day There was 21,000 CVs published in
2022 I believe Now most of them are
nothing burgers They're literally just
blown out proportion overexaggerated For
example it might say you have to right
click on the file change the properties
do this be a local admin and then this
can do this Well I'm never going to do
that It's not It is a vulnerability but
it's not a likely to be exploited
vulnerability So this Felina
vulnerability comes on the news one
morning and it sounds like a nothing
burger So I call our support desk and I
say to them I live 15 minutes from the
office I say when I get in the car hey I
want you to see if this is exploitable
and I speak to a mid-level at best
support guy And by the time I got into
the office he gives me a computer and
it's gone on nothing but threat locker
in monitor mode So we've turned off all
blocking It's got antivirus running on
it Windows Defender and there's a word
document there DocX not docm no macro in
it I double click on this word
document and office starts to load Then
it
crashes and within about 10 seconds
PowerShell launches and the malware is
running on this machine I didn't click
enable macros I didn't click enable
content This malware gave them complete
access to the machine They could scan
the network They could access file
shares They could do whatever they
wanted from the machine And then in 2023
we saw 3CX
um had a backd dooror in it as well
accidentally pushed out malware to their
clients Now there's two things about
supply chain There's the biggest most
common risks and there's the risks that
scare people the most So we have a bunch
of investors We have a board And the
risks that scare the board the most are
intentional sabotage So Novor
accidentally hired a North Korean They
got they caught it before it was too
late A North Korean spy applied to work
at Novor That scares our board and it
scares me but it scares the board more
than anything else scares the board
Someone getting into our code someone
injecting something malicious like they
did in Solar Winds like they did with
3CX and us pushing that code out And we
should be scared of it But the
probability of that affecting your
business is actually small Not
impossible and you should be considering
it but it's
small The other thing is unintentional
back doors Small probability but big
fear
factor because the idea of someone
intentionally getting into your business
like that through a back door is
something that should keep you up at
night Now what should keep you up just
as much and probably more is
vulnerabilities because I can name three
or four intentional back doors that were
put into
software There were 21,000 CVEes
published in 2022 and that's similar to
most years So that's incredibly common
the risk of that software not
intentionally being used by the
vendor but having a vulnerability that
can be exploited later on like the
Felina vulnerability like Exchange and
then also weaponization of
features I would say most ransomware we
see recently is using PowerShell
SevenZip WinRa built-in tools of the
software you run rather than being an
executable
itself And people often overlook that
you don't need to do something malicious
on a machine or run something malicious
because there's enough programs on the
machine that can cause the problems and
do damage right out of the box
We don't know when we make a decision
what is more appro as globally is the
cloud more secure or is onrem more
secure The questions you should ask
yourself when you choose cloud or onrem
are more about do I want to let someone
into my business potentially onto my
network to keep the data safe or do I
want to keep the data outside and that
often depends on the data the company
that's writing the software what their
security is like what their processes
are like you have to consider this but
the bottom line is whenever you run
software inside your organization
whenever you run any program on your
computer that program has access to
everything that you have access to as a
user even if you are not a local admin
So if you go into process manager now
task manager and look at all of the
running processes all of those running
processes can see everything that you
can see which means that Logitech quick
cam support app in the bottom right
corner of your screen that helps you
look 10 years younger when you're on a
Zoom call It can see all of your data It
can see your network shares It can see
your financial files I'm not saying
they're stealing it but if it had a
vulnerability or a back door it could
see
it Every program you run can see it So
what I've already kind of skipped ahead
here but this includes network shares
files other applications So Office can
see
PowerShell Zoom can see PowerShell So if
PowerShell can cause damage those
applications can spawn that Now in order
for something to be exploited it either
has to have an intentional backdoor or
it has to have a vulnerability And a
vulnerability by itself isn't
necessarily
exploitable It has to have a way of
being exploited Now in order for a
vulnerability to be exploited you have
to do one of two things You have to have
an open port So Exchange on the internet
is an open port or it has to ingest data
So pretty much every deployment we do in
any kind of organization now we'll do a
report And we I don't think there's a
single customer I've seen that we
haven't said you're running vulnerable
versions of log
forj Now does that mean it's exploitable
probably not If someone opens a word
document that's got a malicious code in
it and you have a vulnerable version of
Word that's exploitable But if you don't
open a malicious Word document you it's
not exploitable If you have some wheel
alignment software that never ingests
data that's using vulnerable log
software it doesn't mean it's
exploitable
These programs that you're running can
also make changes to your system They
can see your network your entire network
They can see everything that's running
They can scan They can do map They can
get information on your
network So what should we be doing to
control our
environments first thing is assume a
breach Assume something you're running
either has a back door or is going to be
used against you because at some point
it will do At some point you're gonna
have a program that can be used against
you And what you have to say is I want
to limit the amount of damage that can
do Does that mean game over no it
doesn't mean game
over What it means is how do we limit
the damage and the first thing we should
be doing and this seems incredibly
simple is block untrusted
software This does two things One is it
stops users running programs that you
don't know about It's bad enough all of
the programs you trust could be
exploited could have back doors in them
but if you your users can download any
PDF reader they want if they can
download any free software games coupon
clippers you're just making that surface
area attack massive So block all
untrusted software Now that might sound
difficult This isn't 1995 anymore even
2005 Old school whitelisting is like
well that sounds like a disaster but
it's not You deploy an agent it learns
the software you use It matches it with
built-in and known applications And you
can see here on the screen it'll even
show you the country it was developed in
And it will show you what it has access
to in your organization So you can say
I'm running sevenzip This was made in
Russia Do I want to continue to run it
i'm not saying you should or shouldn't
I'm not saying sevenzip is good or bad
And we'll show you all of the risks
associated with it It can be used to
encrypt files Does that mean you
shouldn't use it well it depends If you
have a business case for it maybe you
want to use it but you want to limit
what it has access to We can show you
hey you're running this coupon clipper
made in China that has access to every
password you enter on any
website Does it mean the coupon clipper
is stealing your data probably not The
Chinese would never ever steal
data The other things we should be doing
is configuring our system and hardening
it things like password rotation It's
simple Make sure you're rotating your
passwords regularly so if someone does
get onto one of your machines and they
do get data they can't move around
Enforce encryption um internally and
make sure you have geoloccation where
you can block access to foreign servers
Most attacks now aren't reaching out to
Russia to send data back to Russia
They're reaching out to an AWS server in
Virginia But these things don't cost any
time They don't hurt users So doing
things like that is really easy Turn on
things like dual factor authentication
Someone gains access to your system and
they get your password Dual factor could
be the difference
between not being able to see your files
or not being able to log into your
Office 365 account or being able to log
in Take away admin permissions It
doesn't seem like a big thing and it's
not going to stop ransomware running
Ransomware doesn't need to be an admin
but it makes it harder for them to embed
deep into the system You know there are
registry keys you can change in Windows
that will boot before any of your
security software You can go into
Windows you can create a registry key
and you can say run this software before
anything else runs and it will run
before your antivirus your EDR and
everything else If you're not an admin
you can't change those
keys Dynamic ACL Now this is something
that we introduced two years ago and I
think it's probably one of the most
powerful things we've done
70% of ransomware attacks recently
involve remote encryption And think
you've probably got 500 applications
running on your machine Any of them
could be compromised and now they can
potentially connect to servers encrypt
files 70% according to Microsoft's most
recent
report So we looked at this and said how
can we stop remote encryption well we
can try and detect unusual behavior and
disconnect things from the network
That's not really stopping it It's let's
try and determine unusual behavior is
difficult But there's we can block
anyone connecting to our servers
remotely Well how do users connect to
their file servers in that case to
access files so we went and looked at
this three years ago and we came up with
a solution that allows you to have
dynamic ACL So think about this You come
into your network tomorrow you plug in
your laptop and you do an air map and
you can see RDP open on your server you
can see file shares open you can see
everything else user comes in they can
see the same
thing Attacker comes in they can see the
same thing Now you could put an 802.11
authentication system to prevent anyone
connecting to your network that isn't
one of your company issued devices which
isn't a bad idea However users can still
see the same ports you as the IT
professionals can see And if there's a
vulnerability or they brute force your
passwords they can now
RDP to your servers they can now create
remote
GPUs So what dynamic ACL allow you to do
is specify ACL not on IP addresses but
on devices So when you connect to the
network tomorrow morning and you say I
want to RDP to my server because I'm the
IT guy and I need to do some management
tasks it will actually connect back to
your machine authenticate your machine
before it even responds with an open
port And this is huge because when we
think about someone being on your
network trying to encrypt files they
won't be able to see it The first
question by ethical hackers is can you
turn off threat locker because we can't
see anything on your network and that is
incredibly powerful But you can also do
it remotely on the internet So think
about that exchange vulnerability The
way it was exploited was someone
connected to port 443 If they couldn't
connect
then because it was invisible they
couldn't exploit it We can track all of
your devices your phones your laptops
and automatically open the ports as
needed And we just actually launched the
same configuration in Office
365 So everyone was trying to deal with
token theft Well I have dual factor on
my Office 365 account How do
I stop users logging in without dual
factor well it's easy you turn on dual
factor but then somebody gets the token
they spoof an email they ask them to
enter the onetime code they give them
the onetime code they now have a token
they can connect they can do whatever
they want So what we did is we did the
same thing with Office 365 and we said
"We're going to track your users phones
and we're going to track your users's
computers And if any IP address tries to
connect to your tenant that isn't one of
your trusted devices or isn't the same
IP address as one of your trusted
devices we're going to reject it So if
someone steals your token they won't be
able to see your
tenant Threat locker is a full endpoint
protection platform We offer EDR we
offer MDR but more importantly the key
components we're offering is the ability
to actually stop cyber attacks through
common sense whether you call it zero
trust lease privilege or just default
deny controls stopping untrusted network
traffic stopping untrusted applications
and then controlling exactly what the
applications can do When you deploy
Threat Locker you're going to see a
whole bunch of applications on your
system that you do not like and you are
not going to be able to remove them
because they're probably going to be
important for your business And what
you'll realize is that when we tell you
where they were developed it's going to
scare you
But you can then do things like ring
fence those applications and say "Well
I'm gonna allow this application to run
but I'm only going to allow it to see
this data and this data and this data."
So if it's
compromised it will not be able to step
out of its
lane We can't stop supply chain attacks
but what we can do is limit the damage
caused by them We can continue to do
auditing making sure our vendors are
secure but the most important thing you
can do is harden your environment So
when something is compromised the damage
is limited to that application And then
we back this up with a full EDR that
manages all indicators of compromised
and then can automatically respond based
on custom rules So you could literally
make up a rule that says if I have
someone accesses more than 50 files then
I'm going to block their access to
Dropbox just from
Chrome Or if somebody logs in more than
five times wrong I'm going to shut down
RDP port So you can use all of these
components together to really harden
your
environment We don't have time for Q&A
and unfortunately but please I'm going
